div1.p: Pierce requests that Carter prepare two statements for the lecture series.

div1.head: Letter from C.C. Pierce to Henry Rose Carter, November 2, 1921
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
IN REPLYING
ADDRESS THE SURGEON GENERAL
U.S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
BUREAU OF
THE PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
WASHINGTON
November 2, 1921.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
The Public Health Service is in receipt of your letter of
October 26, in regard to statements on malaria and yellow fever.

The course on the communicable diseases will be handled in
various ways at different institutes. Some institutes may care to
emphasize malaria, others yellow fever.

Will you, therefore, kindly prepare two statements, one
dealing with yellow fever and the other dealing with malaria, each to
contain the following data:

(a) Points to emphasize in a single lecture on the subject
(b) Mistakes to avoid
(c) The two most important books now available on the subject
(d) The three or four most recent and important magazine
articles on the subject.
By direction of the Surgeon General.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, CC Pierce
Assistant Surgeon General. HHM:JFS
